results.title: Looking at sculpture
results.brief_description: Made to encourage people to visit museums and to show how to mkae the best use of such visits. The film studies critically three pieces of sculpture in the Victoria and Albert Museum; a Madonna and child carved in whalebone by an early Anglo-Saxon, carved in wood by Veit Stoss and in terra-cotta by Rosellino. The film comments on the general characteristics of art in the Romanesque, Gothic and early Renaissance pieces respectively. Commentary by Michael Redgrave.

results.title: Looking at paperwork
results.creator_credit: Robert Parker, British Productivity Council and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: Presents an Organisation and Methods approach to administrative practice, showing typical ways of improving its efficiency. Two questions are asked - “How is the work being done?” and “Is the work being done really necessary?”.

results.title: Looking at mammals
results.brief_description: Some of the 2,000 animals on the Hollywood film set of ‘Dr Doolittle’ illustrate the importance of animal classification. While showing the difference between birds, amphibians, reptiles and mammals, the film introduces Flower-Face, the trained hippo; a giraffe that can be ridden; a chimp that smiles on command; along with unusual reptiles and birds.

results.title: Looking at gold and silver
results.creator_credit: Adrian de Potier, J.B. Holmes, Realist Films and Worshipful Company of Goldsmiths
results.brief_description: Surveys the goldsmiths’ and silversmiths’ art, bringing together an assortment of beautiful and ornate treasures from Rome, 7th century Ireland, India, mediaeval England, the work of famous goldsmiths such as Paul de lamerie, and ends with a brief look at contemporary craftsmanship. The objective of the film is to encourage people to look at fine craftsmanship with an educated eye.

results.title: Looking at animals: the dog family
results.brief_description: Introduces the domestic dog as a pet, but also shows it to be a natural hunter. Includes close-ups of jaws and teeth and demonstrates speed of running and methods of swimming. Describes wild dogs of various types and shows working dogs in action.
results.description: Introduces the domestic dog as a pet, but also shows it to be a natural hunter. Includes close-ups of jaws and teeth and demonstrates speed of running and methods of swimming. Describes wild dogs of various types and shows working dogs in action.

results.title: Looking at animals: rhinos
results.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Boulton-Hawker Films and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description: A study of the “white” and “black” rhinoceroses of AFrica and the Indian rhinoceros, showing structure, physical characteristics and movement. Attention is drawn to the urgent need for the conservation and preservation of all species. The white rhino herd at Whipsnade Zoo Park is used to illustrate the role of zoos.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Boulton, Boulton-Hawker Films and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids

results.title: Looking at animals: pigs and hippos
results.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Boulton-Hawker Films and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description: Illustrates the main characteristics of the related group of animals which includes pigs, peccaries and hippopotami. Draws attention to the feet and snout of pigs, and the adaptation of the hippopotamus to an amphibious life.

results.title: Looking at animals: elephants
results.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Boulton-Hawker Films and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description: A study of wild African elephants in their natural habitat. Asian elephants are then shown at work: carrying loads and, ceremoniously bedecked, taking part in an Indian festival. African and Indian elephants are compared and attention is drawn to their main points of difference.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Boulton, Boulton-Hawker Films and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids

results.title: Looking at animals: animals with one foot
results.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Boulton-Hawker Films and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description: The appearance and characteristics of slugs and snails (gastropods) are shown. The muscular action of a common land snail in movement illustrates the meaning of the word “gastropod” (stomach-foot). Both terrestrial and aquatic snails and slugs are studied.
